operation.descriptionCdata:
2113eec6-018e-4720-987d-328e4fa8555b.description=
Get a JSON array which is the subset of an array. The subset can be defined by a start index (fromIndex) alone, in 
which case the resulting array will contain elements from the input 'array' from the 'fromIndex' to the end of the input array. 

The optional 'toIndex' parameter can be supplied, in which case the sublist returned by this operation will contain the elements 
in array starting with 'fromIndex', and include everything up to, but not including, the element at 'toIndex'.

When specifying the index to an array element in javascript it is possible to use the standard notation, where the 1st 
element from the left is index 0, and the right-most element is (n-1), in an array with n elements. However, 
it is also possible to specify elements starting from the right side of the array using negative numbers, in which case
the right-most element is referred to by index -1 and the left-most element is at position (-1 * n), again for an array with n elements.

It is also possible to specify 'fromIndex' and 'toIndex' in either the "from the left" positive format or in the "from the right" negative
format, and even specify them each in a different format in the same call to this operation. However, sublist is always create from 
left to right from the original array, and therefore 'fromIndex' must allayws be to the left of 'toIndex' in the parent array. Any combination
of 'fromIndex' and 'toIndex' which violates this rule (including the case where fromIndex\=toIndex) will return an empty array. 

So, for example\:
With the input array\: [0,1,2,3,4]

fromIndex\=0  and toIndex\=1                  returns [0]
fromIndex\=0  and toIndex\=3                  returns [0,1,2]
fromIndex\=-1 and toIndex not defined   returns [4]
fromIndex\=-2 and toIndex\=-1                returns [3]
fromIndex\=0 and toIndex\=-1                  returns [0,1,2,3]
fromIndex\=1 and toIndex\=1                   returns []




The description of the enclosing folder describes the JSON format with examples,
and the JSON format is described completely at http\://www.json.org.


Inputs\:
    array - String representation of a JSON array. Arrays in JSON are comma seperated lists of objects, enclosed in square brackets ( [ ] ).
Examples\: [1,2,3] or ["one","two","three"] or [{"one"\:1, "two"\:2}, 3, "four"]


    fromIndex - The index of the element in 'array' which will be the 1st element in the sublist array.
Valid values\: Integer between (-1*n) and (n-1) for an array with n elements.


    toIndex - Optional. If this input is supplied, the sub-list will contain the elements from the parent array, starting at the position startIndex, up to, 
                    but not including, the element at toIndex. In other words, the element in the parent array at toIndex is one past the last element 
                    of the sub-list returned by this operation. 
                    If this input is not supplied, the sub-array will contain the elements of 'array' beginning with fromIndex to the end of the array.
Valid values\: Integer between (-1*n) and (n-1) for an array with n elements.

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    failure - The operation failed. See the message in returnResult for details


Results\:
    returnResult - The new JSON array which is a subset of the input array.
operation.name: Get Array Sublist

scriptlet.name: Operation Get Array Sublist (14dcbcdc-22ae-456d-baeb-0e689f2b724c)
